measured_by: 7-point Helpfulness Rating Scale (–3 very unhelpful to +3 very helpful)
justification: “Respondents were asked… ‘Tell us what you think about each of them using a rating from −3 to +3 described in the scale below.’ … The services were described… • Guarantee: A guarantee that you will save a certain percent on your electricity bills if you improve your lighting systems.”

measured_by: 7-point Helpfulness Rating Scale (–3 very unhelpful to +3 very helpful)
justification: The same question listed “Economic Assessment: A cost-benefit analysis of lighting system improvements most relevant for your building,” rated on the identical −3 to +3 scale.
construct: Attitude toward an economic cost-benefit assessment

measured_by: Zero-interest loan preference item (choose ‘full cost up-front’ vs ‘even payments over several years’)
justification: Participants were asked: “Imagine that you have enough money to pay the full cost … but also have the option of making payments … Assume there is 0% interest… Which would you prefer?” The proportion preferring full payment was interpreted as debt aversion.

measured_by: 7-point Desirability Rating Scale for six financing mechanisms
justification: Respondents rated the desirability (−3 very undesirable to +3 very desirable) of options such as ‘Self-funding,’ ‘Commercial loan,’ ‘Utility financing,’ etc., providing a scale-based measure of comfort with debt.
construct: Debt aversion / attitudes toward financing methods

measured_by: Minimum acceptable annual interest rate to lend money (open-ended numeric item)
justification: Survey asked: “What is the minimum annual interest rate you would have to be paid to lend this money? Assume the bank will definitely pay you back (there is no risk).” Responses were used as the risk-free discount rate.

measured_by: Maximum annual interest rate willing to pay on an energy-efficiency loan (open-ended numeric item)
justification: Respondents were asked: “If you were to take out a loan… what is the maximum annual interest rate that you would be willing to pay?” which, together with δ*, was used to estimate δo.

measured_by: 5-point Tenant-Retention Scale (0 Not at all to 4 Extremely)
justification: Question: “To what degree would improving a building's energy performance help retain tenants in that building?” rated on a 5-point scale, quantified this belief.
construct: Belief that energy efficiency aids tenant retention

measured_by: Binary self-report question on ability to pay without external financing
justification: Participants estimated retrofit cost and then answered: “Could you pay for that without getting external financing?” (Yes/No), providing a measure of available capital.

measured_by: Hypothetical choice tasks for occupancy sensors and linear fluorescents
justification: Tables 1 and 2 presented cost/saving data and asked respondents to choose between ‘Invest’ or ‘No change,’ yielding a behavioral intention measure of investment willingness.
construct: Willingness to invest in energy-efficient technology
